citation.article-title: Vibrio tapetis sp. nov., the causative agent of the brown ring disease affecting cultured clams.

p.s: Description of Vibrio tapetis sp. nov.
Vibrio tapetis (ta.pe'tis. L. gen. n. tapetis, of clams [the genus Tapes])
Cells are gram-negative coccobacilli (1.0 to 1.5 by 0.5 μm) motile by means of one polar flagellum.
Grows on marine agar (Difco) and tryptone soya agar (Oxoid) containing 2% NaCl.
Colonies develop within 48 h at 20 ± 2°C and are circular, regular in shape, translucent, and unpigmented.
Grows on thiosulfate-citratebile-sucrose agar (green colonies).
Swarming has not been detected in any of the media tested.
Glucose metabolism is fermentative.
Tests for catalase, oxidase, and nitrate reduction to nitrite are positive.
Facultatively anaerobic.
Chemoorganotrophic.
No growth in the absence of NaCl in the culture medium.
The salt requirement is specific for sodium ion.
Grows in media supplemented with 1 to 3% (wt/vol) NaCl but not in media with salinity higher than 5% NaCl.
Susceptible to vibriostatic agent 0/129 (150 μg).
Growth occurs between 4 and 22°C but not at higher temperatures.
Optimal growth temperature is 18 ± 2°C.
Voges-Proskauer, H2S production, arginine dehydrolase, and lysine and ornithine decarboxylase negative but indole production and β-galactosidase positive.
The strains degrade casein, gelatin, starch, and Tween 80 but are not able to hydrolyze urea and alginate.

Acid is produced from D-fructose, D-glucose, D-galactose, D-mannose, N-acetylglucosamine, and maltose but not from sucrose, L-arabinose, D-melibiose, L-rhamnose, D-sorbitol, myo-inositol, mannitol, or lactose.
V. tapetis B1090T utilizes the following substrates as sole carbon and energy sources: D-fructose, α-D-glucose, N-acetylglucosamine, D-psicose, D-trehalose, Tween 40, succinate, and propionate.
Other substrates specified in Table 2 are not utilized as sole carbon and energy sources.
V. tapetis has been isolated exclusively from manila and fine clams (T. philippinarum and T. decussatus), in which it causes the brown ring disease.
The G+C content of strain B1090T is 43.2 mol% (Tm method).
The type strain of V. tapetis is strain B1090 (CECT 4600).
